prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: If information once considered confidential business information has become available to the public or to others in the industry, it will no longer be considered confidential. For example, in Robin-Nodwell Mfg. Ltd. v. Foremost Developments Ltd.,[1] the plaintiff's employee, Nodwell, attempted to create a tracked vehicle with deep snow capabilities. Although these efforts were unsuccessful, Nodwell's son later created two machines which were similar to the machine developed by the plaintiff. The plaintiff failed to succeed in its action for breach of confidential business information since the mechanical applications that went into the machine (the idea of transmitting power through a drive shaft and through a member moving in a different plane) were not novel, and because the individual who developed the machine “in a general way [right arrow] refused to operate in secret”.[2] Nodwell had allowed knowledgeable people to come and view the machine—people who would have had little difficulty in comprehending its general conception and function. As such, the design was no longer confidential, and the court refused to grant an order protecting the information from further disclosure.

Similarly, in Eldon Industries Inc. v. Reliable Toy Co.,[3] the design of a toy truck was obtained by the defendant, Reliable, from the purchase of a finished product from the plaintiff. The truck was later manufactured by Reliable. The court held that since Eldon had furnished Reliable with the completed article and other material which could be used for construction of the truck, and since the truck had been extensively advertised and pictured in a catalogue and was readily available throughout North America, it could not constitute confidential information.[4]

However, where confidential business information is made public by the defendant, the defendant cannot rely on the fact that the information has already been made public. In the case of Speed Seal Products Ltd. v. Paddington,[5] the defendant, who formerly worked for the plaintiffs designing couplings for oil rigs and jettys, incorporated a company to make and sell the same type of couplings. The defendants had filed for a patent and created a marketing brochure regarding the couplings. The defendants claimed that since the information had become available to the public through the patent application, it could be legally used by the defendants in the creation of their products.
In the ensuing judgment, the court held that there are, in general, three situations in which confidential information may be published:
Publication is made by or with the consent of the person to whom an obligation of confidence is owed. In this case, the person who owes the duty not to disclose is released from that duty.
Publication is made by or with the consent of a third party. In this case, the third party has a duty not to disclose the information without the consent of the plaintiff.
Publication is made by the person who owes a duty of confidence, in which case the person in receipt of the information has a duty not to disclose it without the consent of the plaintiff.[6]

In this case, publication was made by the defendant. The court ruled that since the defendant owed a duty of confidence to the plaintiff, he “cannot be in a better position than he would be if the publication had been made by a stranger”.
